The Story of the Petas in the Form of Bulls
“Why are you like one gone mad,
pulling up the green grass,
saying, ‘Eat, eat,’

analyzed: gata sattam jaraggava  na hi annena pānena
translated: to a bull dead and stiff?🔽For a bull that’s dead doesn’t get up
through food and drink.
You’re the fool and the dunce,
just like the other dunce.”
“These are its feet, this is its head,
this is its body with its bristles.
The eyes are there just as they were,
this is the bull that got up.
The hands and feet of the master,

analyzed: kāyaḥ sīsam ca dissati  rudam mattikathūpasmi
translated: his body and head are seen.🔽He cries on the mound of clay.
Aren’t you the one who’s a dunce?”
“I’m burning, truly burning,
like a pot placed on the fire.
Pour water on me,

original: sabbaṁ nibbāpaye daraṁ.🔽Abbahī vata me sallaṁ,🔽sokaṁ hadayanissitaṁ;
analyzed: sabbam nibbāpaye dara  abbahī vata me salla  sokam hadaya nissita
translated: as if extinguishing a fire.🔽You’ve pulled out the dart🔽that was lodged in my heart.
You’ve removed the grief
of one who was overcome with grief.
I’ve pulled out the dart
and am cool and extinguished.
I don’t grieve or cry
after hearing your words.”
The wise do this.
Those who are compassionate
Turn away from sorrow,
Just as Sujāta did for his father.”
The Story of the Ox-Demon is the eighth.
